stream_context.summary: Kaze begins integrating a newly rewritten Mario collision/step system, then builds art/UI elements (a wanted-poster bulletin board) and shows the mostly-finished minecart chase minigame. He transitions into designing the Wild West bank/Monty Mole mission: creating an elderly Koopa banker NPC, adding a new auto-resizing dialogue box feature, and brainstorming how to guide players to the tunnel entrance without making it too obvious. He closes by discussing overall level storytelling philosophy and considering reordering late-game courses for better pacing.
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces a major engine-side change (new collision/step system), demonstrates a finished-but-buggy minecart mission, adds an important UI feature (auto-sizing dialogue boxes), and makes an explicit pacing decision to reconsider/reorder late-game courses.

findings.summary: Kaze started rewriting Mario’s collision/step handling from scratch and is already running the game on the new system; the goal is significantly more stable, higher-quality collision than typical SM64 hacks, but it still has edge-case bugs (notably ceilings and occasional wrong roll-out behavior).

The new step/collision approach uses a binary search to find the largest viable movement step, accelerated by raycasts, plus additional move verifications (floor existence, sufficient vertical space). Kaze explicitly removed the old step system and earlier raycast-physics approach due to clipping/ceiling-placement problems.

Collision complexity is causing practical development issues: some areas currently have missing collision because too many collision triangles can corrupt RAM, and at least one minecart test crashed due to the unfinished new collision functions.

Spin jump presentation is deliberately grounded in a ‘semi-official’ reference: Kaze chose Mario’s Down-B (Melee) as the closest 1996-era “official” analogue for a spin jump animation, because the prior twirl looked bad; Zeina made the animation and Kaze polished it.
Kaze is implementing a Wild West ‘hat shop’ building with a literal hat on top as a visual joke and landmarking gag (environmental humor used as world-building).

A new bulletin board prop is being added with multiple “wanted” posters (including a meta gag: Kaze is ‘wanted’ for DMCA violation), reinforcing the town’s theme and offering optional readable details.

To make posters work visually in-world, Kaze converts them to fog-shaded decals and fixes render-state issues (Fast64/default ‘environment’ color causing incorrect rendering). He also diagnoses poster blurriness as decal coordinate/quantization alignment problems and corrects it by re-aligning decal coordinates.

Kaze shows the ‘finished’ minecart mission prototype: a secret door in a bar leads to a chase/minigame where Shy Guys flee on minecarts and pressure increases as they close in. Failure handling includes fading out and killing the player if they stray too far; standing in front of a minecart can run Mario over.

Next planned mission focuses on a bank robbery setup: an NPC Koopa banker explains a break-in and a stolen star, implying Monty Mole(s) dug a tunnel. Kaze worries players may stumble into the tunnel/boss too directly without understanding the story clue chain.
Kaze iterates on an ‘old man Koopa banker’ look (beard, glasses, cane) as a vibe-first characterization choice rather than strict biological logic (e.g., “baldness” as a vibe).

While designing the banker NPC, Kaze calls out N64-era rendering constraints affecting character looks: on the N64 pipeline he’s using, animated characters can’t simultaneously rely on both vertex colors and shading in the desired way, limiting effects like a selectively red nose; he considers separate transparent/overlay geometry for facial hair.
Kaze adds a quality-of-life UI feature missing from vanilla SM64: dialogue boxes can now automatically resize to fit longer text, which he explicitly frames as helpful for translation/localization.

For the tunnel entrance gating, Kaze explores multiple readability options (particles along the tunnel path, a comedic fake cardboard boulder, cloth cover) but shifts toward a clearer, more Mario-like gate: a visibly breakable rock/boulder and using the Bomb Cap as the intended tool, also helping justify cap usage in the hack.

Kaze summarizes the current collaboration structure: he’s coding mostly alone on-stream, while Biobak is producing substantial game content and Zeina helps heavily with art/animation; Badub is producing music tracks (release timing depends on when Badub feels ready).

Kaze articulates a core worldbuilding philosophy and pacing concern: not every level should feel ‘made for Mario.’ Some should feel like places that exist independently, with a deliberate mix of story-heavy/character-heavy levels and purely platformy or atmospheric levels. He considers reordering late-game courses to balance that pacing (noting Wild West vs. Fever Dream Castle placement and uncertainty around Course 15/Rainbow Reef).

biobak.summary: Biobak contributes to the stream’s ongoing ‘placeness’/theme discussion about what makes Mario 64 levels feel like real places (Kaze references Biobak’s point when comparing levels).
Kaze flags Biobak as a likely beneficiary of the new auto-resizing dialogue boxes, explicitly connecting it to potential translation/localization work on the project.
biobak.quote: Biobak, you're gonna like this a lot if you want to translate this game.

badub.summary: Badub is actively composing music for Return to Yoshi’s Island; Kaze indicates the public release of music is up to Badub’s preference/timing.

zeina.summary: Zeina created the spin jump animation; Kaze later refined/polished it.
Zeina provides and iterates on art assets during development (bulletin board/wanted posters, attempted glasses, tie/neckwear idea for the Koopa banker).
Zeina’s asset packaging occasionally causes integration friction (e.g., textures not bundled as expected), which Kaze addresses live while importing/fixing assets.

findings.summary: Lilaa raises a Fast64 workflow issue (scenes rendering white), prompting Kaze to acknowledge recurring tool/render-state pitfalls during asset import and render setup.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I don't think Mario 64 is that great either, except for the movement design. The level design itself is not great, but the movement is awesome.
memorable_quotes.context: Kaze explains what he wants to preserve (movement feel) versus what he wants to reinvent (levels as themed places) while building a respectful but new experience.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: We don't want every level to feel like it's made for Mario. We want a lot of them to feel more like they are there and Mario is experiencing them.
memorable_quotes.context: A clear mission statement about worldbuilding and why some levels should feel independent of the protagonist.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: All I want to be is in my basement in silence, making Mario.
memorable_quotes.context: An unfiltered personal line that captures the obsessive, solitary craft side of ROM-hack development amid constant interruptions.

key_stories.title: Rewriting Mario collision to eliminate clipping and instability
key_stories.summary: Kaze begins integrating a brand-new collision/step system intended to outperform typical Mario 64 hacks in stability. The new system is already active in the build, but still produces ceiling-related problems and occasional move/animation mismatches.
key_stories.challenge: The existing SM64 collision/step behavior and prior experiments (including raycast-based physics) allowed clips or introduced new failure modes (e.g., placing Mario below ceilings).
key_stories.process: Kaze removes the old step system and implements a binary-search step solver accelerated by raycasts and extra move validation (floor/vertical clearance checks). He tests it live and notes remaining bugs and edge cases.
key_stories.outcome: Collision feels improved immediately, but the system is unfinished and is implicated in crashes during other gameplay testing; ceiling behavior remains a known issue to solve.

key_stories.title: Minecart chase minigame reaches playable prototype but breaks under new physics
key_stories.summary: Kaze showcases a minecart chase mission accessed via a secret door in a bar, where fleeing Shy Guys create rising pressure as they close in. The mission logic exists and is demonstrably playable, but the build can crash due to ongoing collision rewrites.
key_stories.challenge: Create a self-contained, readable minigame with escalating tension and clear failure states, while the underlying movement/collision code is in flux.
key_stories.process: Kaze designs the secret discovery flow (bar → hidden door) and implements chase progression, boundary handling (fade/kill when too far), and minecart interactions (can be run over; can jump on some minecarts).
key_stories.outcome: Kaze considers it basically “finished” as a mission concept, but flags crashes caused by the unfinished collision functions, making stabilization a prerequisite for final polish.

key_stories.title: Auto-resizing dialogue boxes to support longer writing and translation
key_stories.summary: Kaze implements a text system feature that automatically sizes dialogue windows to fit the message. He frames it as solving a pain point in vanilla SM64 and directly connects it to translation friendliness.
key_stories.challenge: Vanilla SM64’s fixed/small dialogue boxes make longer lines and localized text awkward or impossible without manual tuning.
key_stories.process: Kaze demonstrates the feature live by changing an NPC’s text to something longer and showing the box resize to encapsulate the content.
key_stories.outcome: A new tool-level feature is available to speed writing, reduce UI babysitting, and enable easier localization workflows for collaborators.
key_stories.key_quote: It will automatically find the right size to encapsulate the text.

key_stories.title: Designing the bank robbery tunnel entrance so players infer the story
key_stories.summary: Kaze wants players to understand that Monty Mole(s) robbed the bank and dug a tunnel, but he fears players might simply notice the entrance and stumble into a boss/mission without absorbing the narrative setup. He debates how to hint the entrance without making it too obvious.
key_stories.challenge: Balancing discovery (players feel clever) versus clarity (players don’t miss the intended path or sequence of clues).
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstorms: particle trails along the tunnel route, a comedic fake cardboard boulder/cloth cover, and ultimately a more ‘Mario’ gate using a visibly breakable boulder plus the Bomb Cap as the tool. He considers how visibility might cause accidental discovery.
key_stories.outcome: He leans toward Bomb Cap + breakable rock as the cleanest solution and notes the need to continue refining how the entrance reads visually and narratively.

key_stories.title: Rebalancing course order to improve late-game pacing
key_stories.summary: While discussing which levels feel like ‘places’ versus ‘levels made for Mario,’ Kaze realizes the planned late-game sequence may cluster too many ‘natural place’ levels in a row. He considers moving course placements (Wild West vs. Fever Dream Castle) and remains uncertain about the final Course 15 concept (Rainbow Reef).
key_stories.challenge: Maintaining variety in tone, story density, and ‘Mario-centric’ vs. ‘world-centric’ levels across the full campaign arc.
key_stories.process: Kaze lists several courses and how they differ (story, character interaction, platform focus), then proposes moving Wild West to Course 13 and Fever Dream Castle to Course 12, leaving space to revisit Course 15’s identity later.
key_stories.outcome: A concrete note is made to reconsider course order; final decisions are deferred, but the pacing framework is stated clearly for future planning.

open_questions.topic: New collision/step system roadmap and validation
open_questions.context: Kaze has replaced the old step system with a new binary-search/raycast approach, but ceilings are still problematic and the system can trigger crashes in other missions.
questions: What specific ‘ceiling issues’ remain, and how will you detect/regression-test them across the game?
What were the biggest failure cases of the old step system and the intermediate raycast-physics approach that motivated a full rewrite?
What criteria will convince you the new collision is ‘done’ (test levels, automated tests, community playtests)?

open_questions.topic: Collision triangle limits and RAM corruption
open_questions.context: Kaze says missing collision and testing difficulty come from too many collision triangles causing RAM corruption in certain areas.
questions: What are the practical collision complexity limits you’re hitting (triangle counts, surface counts, per-area memory budgets)?
What strategies are you using to keep collision dense but safe (streaming/loading by zone, simplifying meshes, tooling checks)?
How often do these limits affect level art/layout decisions?

open_questions.context: The minecart chase is shown as ‘finished’ conceptually but crashes due to new collision code still being integrated.
questions: What remains to ship the minecart mission besides collision stability (camera, difficulty tuning, rewards, fail messaging)?
How did you tune the ‘they get closer’ pressure curve, and what player skill level is it targeting?
Will there be additional minecart missions or is this a one-off set piece?

open_questions.context: Kaze adds auto-resizing dialogue boxes and directly mentions translation usefulness (calling out Biobak).
questions: Do you plan full translations, and if so which languages and who will own that work?
How is dialogue authored/stored now (tooling, formatting limits, font constraints)?
Will auto-sizing support edge cases like multi-page text, buttons/prompts, or special characters?

open_questions.topic: Spin jump identity: animation and voice line choice
open_questions.context: Spin jump animation is based on Smash Melee’s down-B; Kaze uses a Smash Melee voice line but worries it feels too ‘not Mario 64,’ and briefly considers hiring a voice on Fiverr.
questions: What makes an element feel ‘respectful’ to SM64 versus feeling like it belongs to a different Mario era?
Will you keep the Smash voice line, edit it further, or commission new audio?
How do you decide when authenticity (era-appropriate) beats clarity/impact (new assets)?

open_questions.topic: Bank robbery mission readability and gating mechanics
open_questions.context: Kaze iterates on how to guide players to the tunnel entrance without accidental discovery, trending toward Bomb Cap + breakable boulder and possibly particle hints.
questions: What is the intended player clue sequence (NPC dialogue → visual tunnel hints → cap acquisition → breakable entry)?
Where and when does the player get the Bomb Cap in the overall game flow?
How will you ensure players don’t brute-force/stumble into the entrance before understanding the robbery setup?

open_questions.topic: Caps as a design pillar (underused in current build)
open_questions.context: Chat suggests Bomb Cap; Kaze likes it partly because caps feel underused and it ties to Yoshi-themed mechanics.
questions: What is the full cap roster in Return to Yoshi’s Island, and what are their intended ‘signature moments’ per world?
How do you prevent caps from feeling optional/forgettable while preserving player freedom?
Are any caps being redesigned mechanically compared to SM64?

open_questions.context: Kaze makes a note to move Wild West to Course 13 and Fever Dream Castle to Course 12, and to reconsider Course 15 (Rainbow Reef) to avoid pacing issues.
questions: What is the current full course list and the ‘pacing map’ (story-heavy vs. platform-heavy vs. pure atmosphere)?
What would make you scrap or replace Rainbow Reef as a late-game concept?
How late in production can you reorder courses without breaking progression logic, secrets, or thematic escalation?

open_questions.topic: Asset sourcing ethics and pipeline reality
open_questions.context: Kaze jokes about taking assets from Google being ‘hypocritical’ to criticize while ROM-hacking, implying a pragmatic approach during prototyping.
questions: What’s the actual policy for third-party references/assets (temporary vs. final), and how do you ensure the shipped game is clean?
What parts of the art pipeline are most fragile (texture bundling, Fast64 export settings, render modes)?
How do you coordinate ‘asset ready’ definitions with Zeina/Biobak so integration is smoother?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions using a custom GCC, calls it open source but hard to find, and says compiler issues made him give up compiling GCC at one point.
questions: What exact toolchain is required to build the project today, and what parts are hardest for collaborators to reproduce?
Is there a plan to package/document the toolchain for long-term preservation of the hack?
How do build/tool issues affect onboarding for contributors?
